details.description: How to get vehicle approval - type approval, individual vehicle approval, single vehicle approval, motorcycle single vehicle approval, voluntary approval, certificate of initial fitness, fees, application forms, replacement approval certificate

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
All vehicles need to be approved to make sure they meet certain safety and environmental standards.

There are different ways you can get approval for a single or small number of vehicles:

  • Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) - if you’re making or importing a single vehicle or a very small number of vehicles
  • Single Vehicle Approval (SVA) - if you’re making or importing a single special purpose goods vehicle of 3,500kgs or less
  • Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval (MSVA) - if you’re making or importing a single 2, 3 or smaller 4-wheeled vehicle
  • Mutual Recognition scheme - if you’re importing a vehicle that’s been approved and registered in the European Union

Type approval

This is to get approval for a type of vehicle instead of having each individual vehicle approved.

  • European Community Whole Vehicle Type Approval (ECWVTA) – used by manufacturers or importers of large numbers of vehicles or those selling in Europe
  • European Small Series Type Approval (ESSTA) – used by manufacturers or importers of very low numbers of specific cars
  • National Small Series Type Approval (NSSTA) scheme - used by manufacturers or importers of modest numbers of vehicles

Help with type approval enquiries

Contact the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) if you need help or information about:

  • IVA
  • SVA
  • MSVA

VOSA enquiries@vosa.gov.uk
0300 123 9000

Contact the Vehicle Certification Agency (VCA) if you need help or information about:

  • ECWVTA
  • ESSTA
  • NSSTA
  • Mutual Recognition scheme

VCA enquiries@vca.gov.uk
0300 330 5797

parts.title: When you need vehicle approval
parts.body:
Most motor vehicles and trailers used on the road need vehicle approval. Normally, the manufacturer or importer will take care of this.

However, your vehicle might not have approval, and you might need to apply for it. Examples of when this might happen include if you’ve:

  • built or rebuilt a vehicle
  • radically altered a vehicle
  • reconstructed a classic vehicle
  • imported a vehicle

Exemptions

You don’t need vehicle approval for:

  • cars and light goods vehicles over 10 years old
  • heavy goods vehicles over 25 years old
  • tracked vehicles, eg a vehicle that runs on tracks rather than wheels
  • vehicles made specifically for use on construction sites, quarries, ports and airports
  • vehicles made for and used by the armed services, fire and rescue forces, or used in maintaining public order
  • trailers with an unladen weight under 1,020kg (except semi-trailers and converter dollies)

If your vehicle needs approval, you must send proof of this in when you apply to register it. If you don’t, the DVLA won’t register your vehicle.

parts.title: Individual Vehicle Approval
parts.body:
Who can use the scheme?

You can use the Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) scheme if you’re making or importing a single vehicle or a very small number of vehicles in the following categories:

  • passenger cars
  • light goods vehicles (up to 3,500kg)
  • buses and coaches
  • medium to heavy goods vehicles (more than 3,500kg)
  • trailers
  • special purpose vehicles, eg vehicles specially designed to hold a wheelchair

You can’t use the normal ‘compulsory’ IVA if your vehicle has been registered before in the UK - you’ll need to use the voluntary version of the scheme instead.

Vehicle identification number

Your vehicle needs a vehicle identification number (VIN) before having an IVA inspection. If it doesn’t have one, apply to your local DVLA office.

Basic and normal IVA

There are 2 levels of IVA inspection: basic and normal.

Basic IVA

A basic IVA involves a visual inspection and other tests to make sure the vehicle meets the necessary standards. You won’t normally need to provide any documentary evidence.

You can apply if you have a passenger car or light goods vehicle in one of these categories:

  • left-hand drive vehicles
  • personal imports
  • amateur built vehicles (kit cars)
  • rebuilt vehicles
  • very low volume production vehicles
  • ambulances
  • motor caravans
  • hearses
  • armoured passenger vehicles
  • a vehicle manufactured using parts of a registered vehicle

For help understanding these categories, download VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme.

Download ‘VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme’ (PDF, 1.84MB)

Normal IVA

If you don’t meet the criteria for a basic IVA, you’ll have to apply for a normal IVA.

This involves a more detailed inspection. Vehicles have to meet extra standards and you’ll have to provide documentary evidence of this.

How to show your vehicle meets IVA standards

There are several ways to prove your vehicle meets IVA standards. For full details, see part 5 of VOSA’s guide to the IVA.

Model reports

One way of proving your vehicle is compliant is by showing it’s the same specification as another vehicle (a ‘master vehicle’) that’s been proved compliant. You do this using a model report.

If a model report has already been produced for your exact model of vehicle, you may be able to use it for a fee. VOSA has a list of model reports and their owners.

Otherwise, you’ll need to pay for your own laboratory tests to be carried out.

Download ‘UK authorised testing laboratories’ (PDF, 21KB)

For more information on model reports, see part 11 of VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme.

How to apply

You need to choose the correct application form depending on your type of vehicle. Send it to the address on the form.

Choosing a test station

Your vehicle will be inspected by VOSA at one of their approved test stations or Privately Owned Test Facilities (POTFs). You should say which one you want to use on your application form.

Download ‘IVA test stations and POTFs’ (PDF, 274KB)

Cost of the scheme

You have to pay a fee for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

What happens next

Wherever possible, VOSA will inspect your vehicle at the test location you’ve chosen and issue an Individual Approval Certificate (IAC) if it passes. You’ll need to use this certificate when you register your vehicle.

Appeal against a refusal

If your vehicle doesn’t pass its inspection and you’re not satisfied with the decision, you can appeal and have a re-examination carried out by an independent inspector.

You must make your appeal within 14 days of the decision and you’ll have to pay a fee. This will be refunded, either partially or fully, if your appeal is successful.

You mustn’t modify the vehicle before the appeal inspection.

You can appeal by downloading and filling in the IVA notice of appeal.

Download ‘IVA notice of appeal’ (DOC, 139KB)

For more information on appeals, see part 8 of VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme.

More information

VOSA has produced an in-depth guide to the IVA scheme.

Download ‘VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme’ (PDF, 1.84MB)

parts.title: Single Vehicle Approval
parts.body:
Who can use the scheme?

The Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) scheme is replacing the Single Vehicle Approval (SVA) scheme. From now on, you can use the IVA scheme for any type of vehicle needing type approval except for special purpose light goods vehicles.

Until 29 October 2014, you can still use the SVA scheme for special purpose light goods vehicles not more than 3,500kg gross vehicle weight that need first licensing and registration in the UK and are less than 10 years old.

Download ‘Guide to the differences between SVA and IVA for light goods vehicles’ (PDF, 294KB)

Application form

Send your completed application to the address on the form along with any relevant documents.

Download ‘SVA application form’ (DOC, 696KB) Download ‘Guidance on completing SVA application form’ (PDF, 135KB)

Cost of the scheme

You have to pay a fee for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

Choosing a test station

Your vehicle will be inspected by VOSA at one of their approved test stations. You can choose which one.

What happens next?

Vehicles that pass an SVA inspection are issued with a ‘Minister’s Approval Certificate’ (MAC).

More information

VOSA has produced an in-depth guide on the SVA scheme.

Download ‘VOSA’s guide on the SVA scheme’ (PDF, 1.01MB)

parts.title: Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval
parts.body:
When you must use the scheme

To register your motorcycle, 3-wheeled or light 4-wheeled vehicle, it must:

  • comply with European Community Whole Vehicle Type Approval (ECWVTA)
  • have a Certificate of Conformity (CoC) to prove this

If it doesn’t have a Certificate of Conformity, it must be inspected under the Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval (MSVA) scheme.

You must also use the MSVA scheme if your vehicle has been radically altered or built using a mixture of parts from previously registered vehicles. For example:

  • amateur built vehicles
  • rebuilt vehicles
  • vehicles converted to a different wheelplan

Eligibility for MSVA

You can use the MSVA scheme for vehicles that:

  • are under 10 years old
  • haven’t been registered before in the UK
  • don’t have ECWVTA

The following types of vehicle are eligible:

  • 2-wheeled mopeds
  • 3-wheeled mopeds
  • light quadricycles
  • solo motorcycles
  • motorcycle combinations
  • motor tricycles
  • heavy quadricycles

These vehicle types are defined in appendix 1 of the MSVA guide, produced by the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA).

Download ‘VOSA’s guide to the MSVA scheme’ (DOC, 518KB)

Partial MSVA

If you have a Certificate of Conformity (CoC), it will say which side of the road and which speedometer units your vehicle is equipped for.

If your vehicle isn’t equipped for use in Great Britain, you must modify it. It will then need a Partial MSVA to check the following items:

  • headlamp dipped beam pattern - this checks the headlamp is suitable for driving on the left
  • speedometer - the speed must be shown in miles per hour (mph) or dual mph and kilometres per hour
  • mirror location - on mopeds fitted with a single mirror, the mirror must be fitted to offside (right) of the vehicle

VOSA has answers to frequently asked questions about the Partial MSVA.

Download ‘Partial MSVA: frequently asked questions’ (DOC, 182KB)

Vehicle identification number

Your vehicle needs a vehicle identification number before having an MSVA inspection. If it doesn’t have one, apply to your Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) local office.

Cost of the scheme

You have to pay a fee for VOSA to inspect your vehicle.

Choosing a test station

Your vehicle will be inspected by VOSA at one of their approved test stations. You can choose which one.

Sending in the application form

Download ‘MSVA application form’ (DOC, 329KB)

Download ‘Partial MSVA application form’ (DOC, 178KB)

What happens next?

VOSA will inspect your vehicle at the test station you’ve chosen and issue a Minister’s Approval Certificate (MAC) if it passes. You’ll need to use this certificate when you register your vehicle.

Appeals

If your vehicle fails MSVA, you can appeal for a re-test within 14 days of the original decision. You’ll have to pay a fee, which will be refunded if the appeal is successful. Contact VOSA to find out how to do this.

More information

VOSA has produced an in-depth guide to the MSVA scheme.

Download ‘VOSA’s MSVA inspection manual’ (PDF, 2MB)

parts.title: Voluntary approval
parts.body:
If your vehicle hasn’t been registered before in the UK, use the normal ‘compulsory’ Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA) scheme.

If your vehicle has been registered in the UK and you need to prove its compliance, use the voluntary version of IVA.

Example
A taxi licensing authority may need evidence of compliance if your vehicle has been modified since it was originally registered.

You’ll need to choose whether to use the basic or normal level of voluntary IVA.

If you drive a taxi, your licensing authority will tell you what level you need to apply for.

How voluntary IVA works

In general, the voluntary and compulsory versions of IVA are exactly the same. The only differences are:

  • you can use voluntary IVA if your vehicle has already been registered in the UK
  • you won’t have the same rights as with compulsory IVA
  • you’ll have to pay VAT on the fee

Cost of the schemes

You have to pay a fee for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

How to apply

To get voluntary IVA for a passenger car or light goods vehicle (up to 3,500 kg), send a completed application to the address on the form.

Download ‘Application for voluntary (non statutory) Individual Vehicle Approval’ (DOC, 709KB)

VOSA has produced guidance on completing the form.

Download ‘Guidance on completing voluntary Individual Vehicle Approval application form’ (PDF, 60KB)

Voluntary application for larger passenger cars, goods vehicles and trailers can be made on the compulsory IVA form.

What happens next?

VOSA will carry out an inspection of the vehicle. If it passes, you’ll be given a ‘Confirmation of Compliance’ notification (not an approval certificate).

Find out more

VOSA has produced an in-depth guide on the IVA scheme.

Download ‘VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme’ (PDF, 1.84MB)

parts.title: Certificate Of Initial Fitness
parts.body:
Who can use the scheme

If you use a vehicle with more than 8 passenger seats to transport people for profit, also known as a Public Service Vehicle (PSV), it must have been approved or have a Certificate Of Initial Fitness (COIF) to register it.

If you use a vehicle with more than 8 passenger seats for private use, you may need to get a Pre-Registration Inspection (PRI).

What vehicles need a COIF

You’ll need a COIF for your vehicle if it:

  • has more than 8 passenger seats
  • will be used for profit
  • doesn’t have approval
  • has approval, but not as a PSV

Only PSV’s with more than 8 passenger seats, eg minibuses or limousines, need a COIF.

Application form

Send your completed application to the address on the form along with any relevant documents.

Download ‘Application for a Certificate Of Initial Fitness’ form (DOC, 692KB)

Cost of the scheme

You have to pay a fee for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

What happens next?

Once you’ve submitted your application, it’ll be sent to your nearest certifying officer who’ll arrange for your PSV’s COIF examination to be carried out at one of VOSA’s approved test stations.

Notifiable Alterations

If you make alterations or modifications to your PSV, you must send details of this to VOSA.

Download ‘Notification of an Alteration to a Public Service Vehicle’ form (DOC, 937KB)

Send your completed application to the address on the form along with any relevant documents.

You don’t need to notify VOSA of like-for-like replacement parts.

parts.title: Inspection fees
parts.body:
You have to pay a fee for the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) to inspect your vehicle.

The cost depends on:

  • whether you’re using the compulsory (statutory) or voluntary version of the scheme
  • the type of inspection (basic/normal or standard/enhanced)
  • the category of vehicle
  • the class of vehicle

Category of vehicle

To find out which category your vehicle is in, see annex 1 of VOSA’s guide to the IVA

Class of vehicle

To see which class of vehicle you have, see annex 2 of VOSA’s guide to the IVA (PDF, 1.84MB).

Download ‘VOSA’s guide on the IVA scheme’ (PDF, 1.84MB)

Individual Vehicle Approval (IVA)

For a full list of IVA fees, see pages 1 and 2 of ‘IVA inspection fees’.

Single Vehicle Approval (SVA)

For a full list of SVA fees, see pages 3 and 4 of ‘IVA inspection fees’.

Motorcycle Single Vehicle Approval (MSVA)

For a full list of MSVA fees, see page 4 of ‘IVA inspection fees’.

Certificate Of Initial Fitness (COIF)

For a full list of COIF fees, see page 4 of ‘IVA inspection fees’.

Download ‘IVA inspection fees’ (PDF, 294KB)

parts.title: Replacement approval certificate
parts.body:
You can apply for a replacement approval certificate by downloading the application form below.

You’ll need to send your application to the test station where your vehicle was first inspected.
